"*cackle*cackle*cackle*! There's no need to worry about that. After all, you all will be sacrificed first. How could anything that happens after that concern you? Entrust your fates to your own children. ...Your children, the embodiment of what you've born, taught and raised. They should be the most suitable ones for you to entrust with your fate...! *cackle*cackle*! Don't look so worried, Kraaauss... Believe in the daughter that you brag is worth ten billion yen. Hehheheh, hehhahahahahaha...!!"

「………まったくね。
"......Exactly.

子どもは親の結晶よ。親の命運を預けるに相応しいわ。お父様にとってもね？」
Children are the embodiment of their parents. It's fitting that we put our fates in their hands. That applies even to you, Father, right?"

「……ふっ、はっははははははは！　肝の据わった女だ、留弗夫にはもったいない！　わっははははははは…！！」
"...Hmph, hahhahahaha! This girl has guts, what a waste on Rudolf! Wahhahahahaha...!!"

「…霧江さん、……あまり挑発しない方がいい。」
"...Kyrie-san, ...it would be best not to aggravate him too much."

「同感だ。今は耐えよう……。」
"I agree. Let's bear with it for now..."

「そうね…。……どうせ私たちはまな板の上の鯉よ。今さら、何も出来やしない。」
"That's right... ...After all, we're just fish on the chopping board. There's nothing we can do now."

「私に対し威勢のいい口を叩くことは出来るがな。嫌いではないぞ、そういう女はァ？　ベアトリーチェも初めはそういう女だった。くっくっくくくくくく！！」
"Hah, though you can insult me with such vigor. I don't dislike that kind of woman, see? Beatrice was like that too, in the beginning. *cackle*cackle*cackle*!!"

「…………お館様。そろそろ本題を。さっきから脱線しまくりです。」
"......Master, perhaps we should get back to the main topic. We've been off track for a while now."

「おお、そうであったな、すまぬすまぬ我が友よ。それでは本題に入ろう。その為に電話を用意しておいたのだ。
"Ah yes, there was that. Sorry, sorry, my friend. Well then, back to the main event. For that, I've prepared a phone.

……紗音、知恵が回るな。もう隠さなくても良いぞ。それは私が用意させたのだ。くっくっくっく…！」
...Shannon, how clever of you. You don't have to hide it any longer. That's something I arranged for. *cackle*cackle*...!"

「し、失礼いたしました……。」
"M-My apologies..."

「……………………。」
"............"

紗音がそそくさと退くと、電話機が照らし出される…。
Shannon quickly withdrew herself, and the telephone was revealed...

「蔵臼よ。ゲストハウスの孫たちに電話を掛けるが良い。そして我がテストを、試練の始まりを彼らに告げるのだ。」
"Krauss, call the grandchildren in the guesthouse. Tell them of the test...and of the start of my trial."

ロノウェが、どうぞとでも言うような仕草で、蔵臼に受話器を取るよう促す。
Ronove motioned for Krauss to pick up the receiver.

「……………嫌だと言ったら？」
".........And if I say no?"

「ほほぅ、取引の余地がどこにあるというのか。お前が電話をせぬというなら、孫たちにはチャンスさえも与えぬ。
"Hohoh, and why do you think you're in a position to negotiate? If you don't make the call, then the grandchildren won't even be given a chance.

右代宮家はこれにて終わり。お前たちは直ちに生贄だッ！！」
The Ushiromiya family will end here. And I'll sacrifice you all right away!!"

「直ちに生贄なら幸運よ。
"You'd be lucky to become sacrifices right away.

……あなたたちの眼前で、子どもたちを先に生贄にされた方が辛いと思うけれど…？」
...Don't you think it'd be more painful to watch the children get sacrificed first, before your very eyes...?"

「……ガ、ァプ。生贄の順番はお館様が決めます。勝手なことを言わないように。」
"...Ga...ap. The Master is the one who decides the sacrifice order. Don't say things on your own."

「リーア、今、私の名前を縮めようとして詰まったでしょ。」
"Lia, you just tried to shorten my name, didn't you?"

「しっ、してません！
"I-I did not!

だから勝手に人の名前を略さないようにっ…！」
And I told you not to shorten other people's names on your own...!"

「……女は実に。」
"...Women truly are..."

「姦しいですな。ぷっくっく！」
"Noisy. Pu ku ku!"

かつて、南條が開業し、その息子に引き継いだ診療所は、今も新島に存在している。
The clinic that Nanjo had opened and later passed on to his son still existed on Niijima.

高齢の医師は、南條の息子ではあったが、その雰囲気はあまり似つかなかった。
This aged doctor was Nanjo's son, but the atmosphere about him was very different.

「わざわざお越し下さり、誠に申し訳ないのですが、特にお話することはありません。」
"I am truly sorry to say this after you have come all this way, but I have nothing in particular to tell you."

南條の息子は、とても淡白にそう言い放った。
Nanjo's son said that very indifferently.

「……あの島の事故が、民放で非常に不謹慎に取り上げられて以来、右代宮氏の主治医であり、友人でもあった父にも、大変心外な関心が多数寄せられました。そのいずれもが何の根拠もなく、また、父のそれまでの業績を汚すものでした。私はそれら全てについて、未だに強く憤慨しています。」
"...After the accident on that island was taken up by the broadcasts in a most indiscreet manner, even my father, who was Mr. Ushiromiya's doctor and friend, was focused upon by many with a wholly regrettable interest. All of it was without proof, and they even managed to defile all of my father's previous achievements. I still feel a great deal of resentment because of that."

「…………無理もないことと思います。私も同じようなものですので。私など、６つの時から延々です。」
"......I think that's understandable. The same thing happened to me. I had to put up with it constantly since I was six."

「そうでしたね。これは失礼。」
"True. My apologies."

医師はようやく、縁寿もまたそういった好奇の目に晒されてきた犠牲者であることを思い出す。
The doctor finally remembered that Ange was also a victim who had been exposed to the same curious eyes as he had been.

「そんなあなたなら、当時の件にもうかかわりたくないという私どもの気持ちもおわかりでしょう。……あれは不幸な事故でした。それを事件だと騒ぎ立てたがるのは、無責任なテレビと雑誌だけです。彼らの態度には心底、うんざりさせられますよ。」
"In that case, you can probably understand why I don't want to have anything to do with that incident. ...That was an unfortunate accident. The only ones who want to make a fuss about it being a crime are those irresponsible TV shows and magazines. I am more than fed up with their attitude."

………右代宮金蔵の数少ない友人ということで、南條は注目を浴びた。
......Nanjo had been bathed with attention for being one of Ushiromiya Kinzo's few friends.

その為、その遺族である息子にもウィッチハンターやマスコミの執拗な取材攻勢があったのだろう。
Because of that, there was probably an aggressive and persistent rush among the Witch Hunters and the press to use Nanjo's son as well, a surviving relative, as a source of information.

……医師は、延々とマスコミ批判を口にし、ひとり憤慨するのだった。
...The doctor went on and on, criticizing the press indignantly.

「お気持ち、よくわかります。私生活に至るまで監視を受け、プライバシーも肖像権も、果ては人権さえも認められてたかわからない私ですから、そのやり場のないお怒り、よーくお察しできます。
"I really understand how you feel. For a person like me, who was observed even in her personal life, and whose privacy, likeness, and even human rights might have been violated, it's really easy to pick up on the anger of someone in your position."

………だからこそ、私の人生をここまで台無しにしたあの事件は一体何だったのか、どうしても知りたいのです。それでここへ来ました。
"......And for that very reason, I want to know, more than anything else, what in the world happened in the incident that so thoroughly ruined my life. So I came here.

………私も、あなたと同じ当事者です。雑誌記者でもインタビュアーでもありません。そこを誤解しないで下さい。
......I'm a related party just like you. Not a magazine columnist or an interviewer. Please, don't get the wrong idea."

私は道楽でこんなところまで来たんじゃない。……私を見下すのもいい加減にして下さい。あの事件で狂わされた人生の傷跡比べをするならば、私とあなたでは比べ物にもならない。」
"I didn't come to do this for fun. ...Quit looking down on me. If we're gonna argue over whose life was most screwed up by that incident, you're no match for me."

「…………ん、……。」
"......Nng, ..."

縁寿はぴしゃりと言い切る。
Ange spoke sharply.

まさか、これほどの強い口調で言い返されるとは思わず、医師は閉口せざるを得なかった。
The doctor, who hadn't imagined that he would be talked back to in such a forceful manner, couldn't help but fall silent.

……縁寿からすれば、医師の泣き言など実に下らないのだ。
...From Ange's perspective, the doctor really was whining over nothing.

いい加減、自分を見下して欲しくない。
どれだけの日々を経て、この島まで来たのか、そろそろ理解してもらってもいい。
She really didn't want to be looked down upon.

It was about time to let him understand how many days had passed for her before arriving on this island.

医師は失言を理解し、しばらくの間、気まずそうに閉口するのだった。
The doctor realized that he'd said something wrong and remained silent for a while, looking uncomfortable.

「当時のことを思い出すのは苦痛でしょうが、ご存知のことがあったら、何でも教えて下さい。もちろん口外はしません。
"I know it's probably painful to remember what happened at the time, but if there's anything you do know, please tell me no matter what it is. Of course, I'll keep quiet about it."

私は、私の人生に決着をつけるために、今日、ここへ訪れています。……私は１８です。あの事件は、私の人生の１２年を奪った。そしてこれからも奪い続けるでしょう。
"I visited here today to bring some resolution to my life. ...I'm 18. That incident took away 12 years of my life. And it'll probably keep on taking.

……私は６歳のあの日から、ずっと暗闇に放り込まれたままなんです。そんな私でも、知る権利がないと仰るんですか…？」
...Since that day when I was six years old, I've remained shut away in darkness. Are you saying that despite that, I still don't have a right to know...?"

「………いや、…失敬。性質の悪い連中ばかりが来ていたので、私もつい身構えてしまったようです。失敬したのをお詫びします。
"......No, ...how rude of me. It seems that since all the others who came were ill-natured folk, I instinctively put up my guard. I apologize for my rudeness.

……わかりました。他言無用を誓っていただけるなら、何でもお話します。」
...I understand. If you'll swear not to breathe a word of this to anyone, I'll tell you everything."

「ありがとう、先生。……ではお願いします。何でも結構です、話して下さい。」
"Thanks, Doctor. ...Then if you would. Please tell me anything you can."

「……知ってのとおり、父は右代宮氏の主治医であると同時に、チェスを通じた友人同士でもありました。その親交は、右代宮氏が六軒島に移り住んできた当時からの、とても長いものでした。」
"...As you know, my father was not only Mr. Ushiromiya's head physician, but his friend through the game of chess. That relationship was very long, stretching back to the time Mr. Ushiromiya moved to Rokkenjima."

「どのくらい仲が良かったのですか？」
"Just how close were they?"

「相当、だったようです。チェスの縁で、先方の屋敷に厄介になることも少なくなかったようです。……私の口から言うのも何だが、右代宮氏は非常に気難しい方でした。そして父はそんな人間と付き合うのに長けた、非常に大らかな人だった。孤独な右代宮氏にとって、稀な友人であったことは想像に難しくないでしょう。」
"Very close, it seems. It seems that their connection through chess led my father to stay at Mr. Ushiromiya's mansion quite often. ...Although I may not be one to talk, Mr. Ushiromiya was extremely moody. And my father was an exceedingly magnanimous man, who excelled at interacting with humans like him. It's not hard to imagine that he was a rare friend for the isolated Mr. Ushiromiya."

「当日は親族会議でした。……右代宮家の親族会議は、資産やその運用などについて厳しく問われる、さながら経営会議のようなものだったとされています。そのような席にまで出席を求められるほどに、南條先生は信頼を得ていたわけですね…？」
"That day was the day of the family conference. ...At the Ushiromiya family conference, the family's wealth and its management were rigorously scrutinized, making it almost like a financial conference. Which means Doctor Nanjo must have gained a trust so great that he was asked to attend even that, right...?"

「父は純朴な医師であり、右代宮家のような富豪の財産運用について助言できるような立場にあったとは思えません。恐らく、当時の右代宮氏は健康状況が優れられなかったでしょうから、その介添えとして呼ばれていたのでしょう。……親友の父なら、おそらく口も硬く、親族会議上の秘密もきっと漏らさないと信頼されていたに違いない。」
"My father was a simple doctor, so I cannot imagine that he was in a position to advise on the management of financial resources for a massively rich family like the Ushiromiya family. He was most likely called there to assist with Mr. Ushiromiya's health, because it was not at its best at the time. ...As Kinzo's close friend, I'm sure my father would have kept his mouth shut, and that he was trusted not to leak the secrets of the family conference."

「……当時の右代宮金蔵はかなり健康状態が悪かったのでしょうか？　カルテが残っていたりはしますか？」
"...Wasn't Ushiromiya Kinzo in very bad health at the time? Were there any medical charts left behind?"

「事故の当日はカルテを持参していたのでしょう。右代宮氏のカルテは、残念ながらフォルダごと失われています。父のクランケですし、私も詳しいことはわかりません。」
"Perhaps he brought the medical charts with him on the day of the accident. I'm afraid to say that the entire folder of Mr. Ushiromiya's medical charts has been lost. He was my father's patient, so I do not know the details."

「事件の前後。何か気になるようなことはありました？」
"Around the time of the incident, did anything strange happen?"

「…………………。……あるにはあります。……ですが、非常に誤解を招きそうなので、あまり言いたくはありません。」
".........Yes, there was one thing. ...However, it seems exceedingly likely to invite misunderstandings, so I very much do not wish to discuss it."

「……何ですか？　それを教えて下さい。」
"...What is it? Please tell me."

医師はしばらくの間、もったいぶったが、そこまで口にしてしまった以上、縁寿はどんなはぐらかしにも誤魔化されない。
For a while, the doctor beat around the bush, but after saying that much, he wouldn't be able to fool Ange by dodging the subject.

やがて根負けし、他言無用をもう一度誓わせた後、それを教えてくれた……。
He eventually gave in, and after making Ange swear herself to secrecy again, told her...

「実は、あの事故の数日後に、私の自宅に郵便が届いたのです。」
"The truth is, several days after that accident, I received something by mail at my home."

「………郵便？」
"......By mail?"

「それはとても奇妙な郵便でした。差出人が私になっているのですが、それは身に覚えのないものでした。何者かが、私の名を騙って出したということです。
"It was very curious. The sender was made out to be me, but I had no memory of it. Someone had faked my name and sent it."

宛て先は北海道の礼文島。……北方領土の話を抜きにすれば、日本の最北端の島です。その宛て先人が何と、礼文島の住所ではありますが………、
"The destination was Rebun Island in Hokkaido. ...Excluding the Northern Territories, it is at the northernmost tip of Japan. The recipient was apparently a residence on Rebun Island, but......

父の名前だったのです。
the name was my father's."

……しかし、送付先住所が間違っているらしく、住所不明の付箋が貼られて、差出人である“私”のところへ戻ってきたわけです。」
"...However, it seemed that there was a problem with the destination address, so it was stamped as Address Unknown...and returned to the sender, `me'."

それは、本当に奇妙な話だった。
It was...truly a strange tale.

差出人は、南條の息子である彼の名が記されている。
……しかしそれは彼が出した郵便物ではないというのだ。
Nanjo's son's name was written as the sender.

...However, he said that he hadn't mailed the letter.

つまり、何者かが彼の名を騙って郵送したことになる。
In short, that meant someone had faked his name and sent it.

そして宛て先は、北海道礼文島の“南條輝正”。
The destination was `Nanjo Terumasa', on Hokkaido's Rebun Island.

しかし存在しない地番が記されており、現地の郵便局は配達できず郵便物を“差出人である南條の息子”に返送してきたわけだ……。
But the lot number written on it didn't exist, so the local post office had been unable to deliver it and instead sent it back to `the sender, Nanjo's son'...

「……中身は何だったんですか？」
"...What was inside?"

「………………………。……本当に他言無用でお願いします。私も、非常に迷惑しているんです。かといって、捨てるわけにも行かず……。」
"...............I do ask that you keep silent about this. It is extremely troublesome to me as well. And even so, I cannot throw it away..."

医師は立ち上がると本棚に向かう。
The doctor stood up and faced a bookshelf.

そこには何十巻もの、観賞用だとしか思えない辞典群がずらりと並び、自分はインテリであるとこれ以上なく主張していた。
There was packed a group of dictionaries that could only have been ornamental, meant to make it very clear that the owner was an intellectual.

その内の中ほどから何冊かを抜き出すと、その奥に大判の茶封筒が隠されていた。
When he pulled several volumes out from there, a large, brown envelope peeked out from behind them.

それを取り出し、机の上に放る。
He took that out and tossed it onto the desk.

セロテープで厳重に封印されており、その変色と乾き具合から、１２年間封印されてきたことをうかがわせた……。
It had been been carefully sealed with cellophane tape, and its faded color and dryness made it clear that it had been sealed 12 years ago...

「くれぐれも、………他言無用でお願いします。」
"I ask most solemnly for your silence on this matter."

しつこいくらいに念を押しながら、医師は高級なペーパーナイフで封印を解く。
Being so persistent that it was annoying, the doctor removed the seal with a paper knife.

……そして封筒を傾けると、なかから開封済みの郵便封筒が滑り出してきた。
...Then, when he tilted the envelope, an already opened mail envelope spilled out.

封筒には重みがあり、手紙以外のものが入っていることを想像させた。
The envelope had a weight to it, hinting that there was something other than a letter inside.

………宛て先人は、確かに南條輝正。
......The recipient...was certainly Nanjo Terumasa.

これだけを見ると、……あまりに衝撃的だ。
Just seeing that...was a huge shock.

あの事件で、南條は死体が発見されず、危難失踪によって死亡の扱いになっている。
Following that incident, Nanjo's corpse had not been found, and he had eventually been treated as dead after going missing under extraordinary circumstances.

……にもかかわらず存在する、北海道の南條に宛てた手紙。
それはまるで彼が、自らを死んだと偽って、北海道に逃亡したという風にさえ読み取れる。
...And despite that, this letter addressed to a Nanjo in Hokkaido existed.

One could almost take this as a sign that he had faked his own death and escaped to Hokkaido.

「……南條先生は、本当に北海道に存在を？　あるいは、同姓同名の人物が北海道に？」
"...Was Doctor Nanjo really in Hokkaido? Or else, was there another person with the same first and last names in Hokkaido?"

「父が、何かの事情で事故を逃れ、北海道で存命していたのだとしたら、私たち家族にとっては、事情にかかわらず嬉しいことです。
"If my father had somehow escaped from the accident and lived on in Hokkaido, that would have made us of his family very happy, regardless of the circumstances.

私も初めはその可能性を考えました。……しかし、この封筒の送付先住所は存在しないのです。つまりこの封筒は、届くはずのない郵便なのです。」
I also thought of that possibility at first. ...However, the envelope's destination address does not exist. In short, this envelope was mail that had no way of reaching him."

「…………送付者が、正しい住所を書き損じた可能性は？」
"......Is there a possibility that the sender miswrote the correct address?"

「もちろん否定はできません。ですが、住所の番地を見る限り、どうもそうは思えないのです。」
"Of course, I cannot deny it. However, judging from the residence's house number, I find that hard to believe."

「………
北海道
礼文島
礼文郡
礼文町、
１−２−３４−５６７。…………………。」
"......

Hokkaido,

Rebun Island,

Rebun County,

Rebun City,

1-2-34-567. ........."




礼文町まではいい。
Up until Rebun City, it's fine.

…しかしその後の数字は、１２３４５６７と連番で、少々の不真面目感は拭えない。
まるで、子どもがでたらめな住所をでっちあげたかのような、そんな印象を持った。
...But I just couldn't wipe away the feeling that the sequential number after it, 1234567, was a little insincere.

It felt like a fake number that some kid had made up.

「恐らく、明らかに存在しない住所をでたらめに書いたのでしょう。この封筒は初めから、存在せ
"They probably wrote a nonsense number that clearly didn't exist. I think it's natural to assume that, from the very beginning, this envelope was sent to a nonexistent residence to which

ず~ib~届くはずのない住所~ib~に送付されたと考えるのが自然だと思います。」
~ib~it had no chance of being delivered~ib~."

送付先住所が存在しなければ、郵便物は通常、差出人に返送される。
If the destination address doesn't exist, mail is generally returned to the sender.

ただ、不完全な住所ではあっても、現地の郵便局の好意的努力により、可能な限り、差出人が意図した送付先が存在しないか調査されることが多い。
But even in the case of an incomplete address, the local post office will often courteously, and to the best of its ability, research to find whether the sender's intended destination exists.

それでも見つからない場合、数日の調査を経て返送されるケースもある。
When they still can't find it, the mail is sometimes returned after an investigation of several days.

この封筒もそうだったらしく、切手の消印は、１０月３日になっていた。
It seemed that the same thing had happened with this envelope, and the stamp was postmarked on October 3.

消印は新島内だ。
It was postmarked on Niijima.

新島から礼文島は遠く離れている。
Niijima was a long way away from Rebun Island.

その上、住所もでたらめ。
……返送には１週間以上の期間を経ていた。
On top of that, the destination was also nonsensical.

...It had taken more than a week for the mail to be returned.

……つまりこの封筒は、不定期間を経て差出人に返送されることを、初めから目論んでいた可能性が極めて高いということだろう。
...In other words, there was probably a high chance that having the envelope returned to the sender after an unfixed amount of time...had been the goal from the very beginning.

何のためにそんなことを………？
Why do something like that......?

何が送られてきたのかを問う以前の段階でさえ、この封筒は謎に包まれている……。
Even before asking what it was that had been sent, this envelope was already wrapped in mystery...

「………………中身は？」
".........And inside it?"

「どうぞ。」
"Go ahead."

医師に許可をもらい、すでに口の開いている封筒を傾ける。
After getting the doctor's permission, I tilted the already opened envelope.

すると中から、畳まれた小さな手紙と、ナンバープレートの付いた小さな鍵。それと磁気カードが溢れ出てきた。
From the inside came a small, folded letter, and a small key with a number plate attached. Then, a magnetic card slid out.

鍵のナンバープレートにはＡ１１２と刻印されている。
……何を指すのかはわからない。
A112 was engraved on the key's number plate.

...I didn't know what it meant.

磁気カードは真っ黒で、金文字が刻印されている。
The magnetic card was pitch black and had gold characters engraved in it.

英語で、メンバーズと記されていた。
漆黒に金文字のカードデザインは、かなりの高級感を感じさせる。
`Members' was written in English.

The jet-black, gold-lettered card design made it feel like something very high-class.

……しかしもちろん、それだけでは何のカードなのか見当もつかない。
...But of course, I didn't have a clue what kind of card it was just from that.

……折り畳まれた手紙を広げる。
...I unfolded the letter.

そこには非常に簡潔に、以下のことだけが記されていた。
Its contents were extremely brief, and only the following was written:

０７１５１１２９。
07151129.

そして、誰もが知る日本の某巨大銀行の名が記され、本店とも書かれていた。
Also written was the name of a certain massive bank known throughout Japan, as well as the words `Central Branch'.

……それだけだ。
...That was all.

"And this is......?"

「……………。………貸し金庫のカードと鍵、そして暗証番号でした。それも普通の貸し金庫ではない。特別な顧客のみに許されているらしい、不気味な貸し金庫でした。」
"............It's a card, a key, and a PIN for a safe-deposit box. And it wasn't a normal safe-deposit box either. It was an unsettling one, which was apparently reserved only for special clients."

医師は、父の葬式後の身辺整理を終えた後、銀行本店を訪れた。
After he finished putting his affairs in order following his father's funeral, he had visited the bank.

……暗証番号と鍵と磁気カード。
何か重要なものが預けられていることは間違いなく、それが何であるか、関心を持ったのは当然のことだった。
...PIN and key and card.

There was no doubt that something of great importance was kept there, and he had been naturally curious about what it might be.

初めはどうすればいいかわからなかった。
At first, he hadn't known what to do.

……本来、自分の所有するものではないカードだ。
...The card wasn't something he'd owned in the first place.

勇気を出して行員にカードを見せると、明らかに格のある行員に対応が変わり、地下４階の大金庫室に案内された。
When he mustered up his courage and showed the card to a bank clerk, he was then switched to a clerk of clearly high status...and was guided to a large vault on the fourth basement.

そこに至るまでのセキュリティは厳重。
The security on the way there was strict.

医師も、不動産の謄本などの重要なものを貸し金庫に預けた経験があるが、ここのそれはまったく格が違っていた……。
The doctor had himself stored valuable items such as real estate transcripts in safe-deposit boxes before, but this was something on a whole different level...

「……私の使っている貸し金庫の手続きと違い、カードと暗証番号、そして鍵を持っているならば、本人確認は行なわれないというシステムでした。……ですが、とにかく厳重な金庫室で、その物々しさに怯えました。……こんなところに預けざるを得ない、どんな物騒なものが待ち受けているのか、と。」
"...Unlike the procedure at the deposit box I had been using, with this system, as long as you had a card, a PIN, and a key, you didn't need to have your identity confirmed. ...But, anyway, I was frightened at how imposing that secure vault was. ...And I wondered what kind of shady objects might await me that had to be stored in a place like this."

「…………それで？」
"......And then?"

「カードをリーダーに通すと、暗証番号の入力を求められました。そして、そこにある８桁の数字を入力すると認証され、金庫室への入室が認められました。……すごい光景でしたよ。まるでＳＦ映画のような世界だった。薄暗い銀色の広大な部屋に、びっしりと金庫の扉が埋め尽くされているのです。」
"When I passed the card through the reader, I was asked to input the PIN. And, after that eight-digit number was input and authenticated, I was permitted access to the vault. ...It was an incredible scene. A world like something from a sci-fi movie. The massive, dimly-lit silver room was covered with doors to safes."

その部屋に、行員を伴い入場した。
He had entered that room along with the clerk.

カード認証の時点で、権利のある金庫は確定しているらしく、開けられる金庫には緑ランプ、開けられない金庫には赤ランプが点灯していた。
It seems that as soon as the card was read, the vaults he had a right to were determined, so that safes he could open were lit with a green light, while those he couldn't open were lit with a red one.

「Ａ１１２は、それらの金庫のうちの１つを示すものでした。……ちなみに、それ以外の金庫にもずらりと緑ランプが点灯していました。２０個以上はあったと思います。あるいは他の一角にももっとあったのかも。
"A112 was one of those safes that were marked. ...By the way, there were several other safes marked with a green lamp besides that one. I think there were at least 20. There might even have been more in the other corner.

……いずれにせよ、私の鍵はＡ１１２のみ。他の金庫の中身を確かめる術はありませんでしたが。」
...In any event, I only had the key to A112. I had no way of checking the contents of the other safes."

医師は行員が立ち会う中、開錠し扉を開く。
As the clerk watched, the doctor had unlocked and opened the safe.

すると大き目のキャビネットのような金庫の引き出しが開き、……中から高級感あるジュラルミンケースが姿を現した…。
When he did, a safe drawer like a large cabinet had opened, ...and an expensive-looking duralumin case peeked out...

それは別室に運び込まれ、そこで初めて行員は退室し、その中身と対面することとなった……。
That was carried into a separate room, where for the first time, the clerk left, and he was introduced to the contents...

「中身は………？」
"And the contents were......?"

「……………………。
".........

…………現金でした。」
......Cash."

"Cash? How much?"

「新札の百万円の束はちょうど厚みが１ｃｍになると聞いたことがあります。それが、………これだけのジュラルミンケースの中に、びっしり詰められていたのですから…。……多分、１億はあったでしょう。
"I have heard that a pack of one million yen in fresh banknotes is precisely one centimeter thick. Since those were packed tightly into a duralumin case of such a size, ...there was probably 100 million in total.

数えたわけではないからわかりません。手すら触れませんでしたから。私はすぐに直感しました。これは危険な金だと。」
I don't know, because I didn't count. I didn't even touch it with my hands. I realized at once. This was dangerous money."

１億ものかさばる現金を、そのままカバンごと金庫に預けることは普通しない。
……口座に入金して、数字に変えてしまった方がはるかに取り扱いが楽だ。
It isn't normal to store a whole hundred million yen in cash in a case in a safe like that.

...It's much easier to deal with if you put it into an account and turn it into numbers.

それが出来ない時点で、何か良からぬ事情のある現金であることは明白だった……。
When someone is unable to do that, then it's clear that there's something wrong with that cash...

「……私は頭が真っ白になり、すぐに関わり合ってはならないと直感しました。」
"...My mind went blank, and I instantly realized that I mustn't get involved."

"So, you didn't use it at all?"

"Correct. I locked it back up just as I'd found it, returned it to the original safe, and left. ...I have thought about throwing away that key and card, but I don't know what will happen. For that reason, I have been hiding it in the back of this bookcase for a full 12 years. ......I still do not know what kind of money that was."

「……この封筒をお借りすることは出来ますか？」
"...Could I borrow this envelope?"

「いいえ。この場で見るだけにして下さい。」
"No. Please just view it here."

「…………………。
"......

……わかりました。ではちょっと失礼します。調べ物を。」
...Understood. Then, if you'll excuse me. There's something I want to investigate."

私は下ろしていたナップザックからお姉ちゃんの魔導書を取り出す。
I took Onee-chan's grimoire from the knapsack I had set down.

……そしてベアトリーチェがお姉ちゃんに記した文章のページを開き、その筆跡と照らし合わせる……。

…………特長ある筆跡は、間違いない。
......There was no mistake about the characteristic handwriting.

The one who had sent this hundred million yen in cash......was Beatrice herself...

でも、………何だろう。
何かが引っ掛かる……。何だろう………。何だろう………。

Something's bugging me... What is it......? What could it be......?

"......Y-Yeah. I'm pretty sure I got something like that in the mail.

かーちゃん、あれはどこにしまったっけなぁ？！」
Hey Ma, where'd you put that?!"

同じ封筒と内容物は、かつて熊沢と同居していた息子にも届けられていた。
The same envelope and contents had been sent to Kumasawa's son, who had once lived with her.




ただ、日々が忙しく、ばたばたとしているうちに、そのまま忘れてしまっていたようだった。
But he had been very busy in the days since, and seemed to have forgotten about it while running around all over the place.

しかし、その奇妙な中身は記憶に留まっていたらしく、縁寿がそれを告げるとすぐに思い出してくれた……。
However, its strange contents had apparently stayed in his memory, and he remembered as soon as Ange mentioned it to him...

しばらく待っていると、お前さんはすぐにしまった場所を忘れる、と愚痴を言いながらへの字口の奥さんが、例の封筒を探し出してきてくれた……。
After a bit of a wait, his thin-lipped wife found the envelope, complaining that he always forgot where he put things right away...

差出人と宛先人の手口は南條の息子のものとまったく同じ。
The modus operandi for the sender and recipient was the same as Nanjo's son's.

差出人が熊沢の息子になっており、宛先人は熊沢チヨ。
The sender was made out to be Kumasawa's son, and the recipient was Kumasawa Chiyo.

そして送付先住所は沖縄県。
沖縄県八重山郡与那国町、１−２−３４−５６７。
And the destination address was in the Okinawa Prefecture.

Okinawa Prefecture, Yaeyama County, Yonaguni City, 1-2-34-567.

与那国島は日本の最西端。

Yonaguni Island was at the western-most tip of Japan.

And the lot name was the exact same sequential number that had apparently been chosen without much care.

……これで確信する。
確実にこの封筒は、差出人に返送されることを目論んでいるのだ。
...Now it was certain.

This envelope was definitely sent with the goal of having it be returned to the sender.

中身もまったく同じ。

ナンバープレートの刻印はＡ１１３。
The inscription on the number plate was A113.

恐らく、金庫の中には同じようにジュラルミンケースがあり、１億円の現金が詰められているのだろう……。
Most likely, inside the vault was the same kind of duralumin case, packed with a hundred million yen in cash...

「……死んだお袋が冥土から送ってきたような気がしてねぇ。中身もよくわからんし、薄気味悪いんで、ずっと放ったらかしにしてて、今日まですっかり忘れてたんですわ。
"...I get the feeling my dead mother sent it to me from beyond the grave. Don't really get what's inside, and it's creepy, so I just left it alone all this time, and totally forgot about it until today."

……お嬢さんはこれが何か、ご存知なんですかね？
"...So, you know what this is, girl?

ひょっとして、あんたんとこにも同じものが…？」
Could it be that the same kind of thing came to your place...?"

"...What is it, Ange-sama?"

...I've got it... ......I know..."

...I've remembered...!!

A strange envelope was also sent to me...12 years ago...!!

家族を全て失い、塞ぎこんでいた。
…でも、本当におかしな郵便物だったので、わずかに記憶に残っていたのだ。
After losing my entire family, I was depressed.

...But it was a really strange thing to come in the mail, so I still had a faint memory of it.

それは、出した覚えもないのに、自分が差出人になっているおかしな郵便。
It was a strange letter, which I had no memory of sending, but which had me as the sender.

宛先の住所は忘れたが、宛先人は右代宮留弗夫。

I forget the destination address, but the named recipient had been Ushiromiya Rudolf.

My father.

死んでしまったお父さんからの手紙だと思って、中を開けたら、よくわからない鍵とかカードが出てきて、困惑したのを覚えてる。
I remember how disturbed I was when I got a letter I thought was from Father, opened it up, and found a key and a card that I didn't really understand.

私はがっかりし、それをどこかに放り出してしまったはず…。
I felt let down and threw it away somewhere, I think...

あの封筒はどこにやってしまっただろう？

Where did I put that envelope?

I probably lost it somewhere in the chaos that followed.

今となっては、その内容を確かめる術もない。
By now, I have no way of checking its contents.

しかし、何となく察しはつく。

暗証番号のメモと鍵とカードが入っていたに違いないのだ……。

Without a doubt, there had been a key, a card, and a note with a PIN inside the envelope...

「……ベアトリーチェ……。……これは何のつもりよ…？　あいつは、全ての遺族にこんなふざけたカネをばら蒔いたというの？　………死んだ後も愚弄するなんて、……許せない………。」
"...Beatrice... ...What was she trying to do here...? So, did she hand out this stupid money to all the surviving relatives? ......I won't forgive her...for mocking them even after their deaths......"

『うりゅ…、うりゅ……、縁寿………。』
『Uryu, ...uryu, ...Ange......』

さくたろがおろおろする。
……その心配そうな顔を見ているうちに、少しずつ興奮は冷めて行った…。
Sakutarou acted nervously.

...As I looked at his worrying face, my agitation began to cool off bit by bit...

"I'm sorry... My hatred of Beatrice isn't anything new.

As Sakutaro buried his head in my stomach, he urged me to stay calm.

「………この封筒の送付はつまり、ベアトリーチェによる事件の、計画性を裏付けるものかしら。」
"......I wonder if this envelope was sent to support the theory that Beatrice was behind that crime."

......But it raises a few questions. Why use such an uncertain method?"

「えぇ。だって、何日で郵便が戻ってくるかなんて、事前には想像もできないじゃない。……郵送先の郵便局が調査し、送付先不明と判断し返送するまでの期間なんて、普通は想像も出来ない。」
"Yes. After all, no one could even guess at how many days it would take for the mail to return before you used this trick. ...Normally, you couldn't even guess at the amount of time it would take for the receiving post office to do their research, determine that the recipient was unknown, and return it."

『そう言えばそうだね……。ちゃんと到着の期日を決めて、そういう郵便で出した方が確実なのにね……。うりゅ…。』
『Yeah, now that you mention it... It'd be more dependable if they just set an arrival date and mailed it that way... Uryu...』

「……まぁ、でも。前日に投函したんなら、どんなに早く戻ってきても、きっと月曜日以降の到着になったでしょうし。死者からの手紙を気取りたかったんじゃないかしら。」
"...Maybe, but still, if they mailed it the day before, then no matter how quickly it returned, it would probably arrive Monday or later. I wonder if they wanted to make it seem like a letter from the dead."

「……死者からの手紙、か。
"...A letter from the dead, you say?

……確かにね。あれは驚くし、嫌な気持ちになるわよ。……死んだ家族の名前が表に大きく書かれている郵便物が、物々しい付箋付きで郵便受けに放り込まれているんだから。……でも、私は何か腑に落ちないわ。私だったら期日指定郵便にする。ひょっとしたら、想定しない日に届くかもしれないという不安定さが、私にはどうしても理解できないの。」
...You're right. It surprised me, and it made me feel bad. ...Some mail with my dead family's name written on the outside in large letters...was thrown into the mailbox with an ominous label attached. ...However, it doesn't really make sense to me. I would've mailed it to arrive on a specified day. I just can't understand why someone would allow the uncertainty of it arriving on a day other than the one they imagined."

『…………………うりゅ。……でも、確かにそういうの、ベアトらしいかなって思う。』
『.........Uryu. ...But it really does sound like Beato to me.』

「え？　あなた、ベアトのことわかるの？」
"Huh? You...know about Beato?"

『……ちょっとしかお話したことないけど。……でも、ベアトならこういうことをするかなぁってのが、何となくわかるの。
『...Well, I only talked with her a little. ...Still, I can pretty much accept that Beato would do something like this.

………マモンも、何となく想像がつかない？　ベアトって、こういう悪戯、好きだよね？』
......Can't you imagine that happening too, Mammon? Beato likes pranks like this, right?』

「………………。
"......

………確かにそうかも。……ベアトリーチェさまなら、死者からの手紙、みたいな悪質な悪戯は、やりかねないと思います。」
......Yeah, that might be true. ...I wouldn't put it past Beatrice-sama to try a vicious prank like a letter from the dead."

『うぅん、それだけじゃなくて。………絶対確実な方法じゃなくて、ちょっぴり不確実な方法の方を、ベアトリーチェは面白がるの。』
『No, that's not all. ......Beatrice would find it more interesting to do it through an uncertain method, instead of one that was absolutely certain.』

「………不確実な方法を、面白がる…？」
"......She would find an uncertain method...interesting...?"

真里亞お姉ちゃんの日記を思い出す…。……ベアトリーチェと遊んだ記述も結構ある。
I remembered Maria onee-chan's diary... ...It had described playing with Beatrice very often.

その中でベアトは真里亞と一緒に、親族の大人たちに何かの悪戯を仕掛けることがたまにあった。
During those times, Beato sometimes played pranks on the adult relatives with Maria.

しかしその悪戯は、いつもちょっとした魔女の美学があった。
But those pranks always had a touch of witch aesthetics.

それは、………不確実である方が面白い、というものだ。
Which was......that they were more interesting when they were uncertain.

ある日、真里亞お姉ちゃんたちは、持参したゼンマイ式の小さなミニカーを悪戯に使うことにした。
One day, Maria onee-chan and Beato decided use a wind-up minicar she had brought for a prank.

ミニカーをバックさせると車輪のゼンマイが巻かれ、放すと勢い良く走り出すという、当時流行った玩具だ。
It was a popular toy at the time, and if you made the minicar back up, it would wind up the spring in the tires, and when you let go, it would race forwards.

そのミニカーを、ゼンマイを巻いた状態でミルクポットの影に置いた。
They had wound up that minicar and set it behind a milk jug.

……つまり、ミルクポットを持ち上げると、勢い良くミニカーが走って飛び出し、相手は驚くという悪戯だ。
...In other words, the prank was that, if you lifted the milk jug, the minicar would jump forwards and surprise whoever did it.

この悪戯に誰かが引っ掛かって欲しいと、お姉ちゃんとベアトは、物陰からずっと大人たちのティータイムを見守っていた。
Hoping that someone would get caught in this prank, Onee-chan and Beato had watched the adults from the shadows for their whole teatime.

誰が引っ掛かるかと楽しみにしていたが、とうとう誰も罠のミルクポットを手に取らず、悪戯は不発に終わってしまった……。
They were looking forward to seeing someone get caught by it, but no one moved the trap milk jug, and the trap ended in a misfire...

その時、「絶対に誰かが引っ掛かる場所に仕掛ければ良かった」とぼやくお姉ちゃんに、ベアトはこう言ったらしい。
When Onee-chan had then muttered `We should've put it somewhere where it would've definitely caught someone', Beato apparently said this:

「誰が引っ掛かるかわからず、引っ掛かるかどうかさえわからない罠の方が、ハラハラして面白い」と言うのだ。
"The most interesting and thrilling traps...are those where you don't know who'll get caught, or even if anyone will get caught at all."

……絶対に引っ掛かる罠では、確かにそういう興奮はないかもしれない。
...It's probably true that you wouldn't get this kind of excitement from a trap that would certainly go off.

……そういう記述は複数箇所あり、ベアトリーチェという魔女は、わりとランダムなスリルを好む気まぐれな性分があることが推察できた……。
...Similar accounts occurred in multiple places, making it possible to guess that the witch called Beatrice had a fickle character and loved a random thrill...

気まぐれとは、何とやりにくい相手なのか。
A fickle person is very hard to deal with.

１２年前の魔女が何を企んでいたのか、……チェス盤が引っ繰り返せない。
I can't spin the chessboard around...to find out what that witch from 12 years ago was planning.

縁寿は、それらを吟味しながら、そわそわと視線を躍らせた。
As Ange examined these, her gaze darted from place to place.

すると、ふと壁に興味を示す。
Then, she suddenly showed interest in the wall.

そこには、写真の入った額がたくさん掛けられていた。
There, several framed pictures were hung.

それらは熊沢家が親族で集まったり、遊びに行ったりした時の記念写真が多く、熊沢を写したものも多かった。
Many of them were commemorative photos from when the relatives of the Kumasawa family gathered or went somewhere to play, and Kumasawa was in several.

今にも、ほっほっほ…、と快活な笑い声が聞こえてきそうになるその笑顔。
...And she still wore a smile that made it so you could almost hear her lighthearted `hohohoh' laugh.

……遠い記憶だが、確かにこんな雰囲気の元気のいいおばあちゃんだったことを覚えてる…。
...It's part of my distant memory, but I definitely remember that she was this sort of cheerful old lady...

「熊沢さんは、事件の直前に変わった様子はありましたか…？」
"Did you notice anything different about Kumasawa-san in the days leading up to the incident...?"

「いいやぁ。いつも通りに見えたなぁ。……親族会議はぴりぴりするから、辛い辛いと漏らすのはいつものことでしたし。」
"Nope. She looked the same as ever. ...The family conference put her on edge, so she was always grumbling about how tough it was."

「…………？　……これは？」
"......? ...What's this?"

たくさんの額の中に、人物写真ではないものが含まれていた。
Among the several frames, there was one that had something other than a picture of people in it.

それは洋館か何かの扉かレリーフを拡大して撮影したものだった。
It was a picture of an enlarged relief of a door from a Western-style house or something.

……特に面白い被写体にも見えず、むしろなぜわざわざ撮影したのかが気になった。
...You couldn't see any interesting subject in particular, which actually bugged me a bit as I wondered why anyone had gone to all the trouble of taking it.

近付いてみると、ペンで何か文字が記されているのに気付く。
As I got closer, I realized that some characters had been written with a pen.

「……あぁ、それはお袋の形見分けでもらってきた写真ですわ。多分、例の黄金伝説に関係したヤツではないかと。」
"...Oh yeah, that's a photo I got when Mother's belongings were distributed. I think it probably has something to do with that `Legend of the Gold' thing."

「魔女の碑文ですか？　１０ｔの黄金の隠し場所を示すと噂される…。……熊沢さんも挑んでおられたんですね。でも、これは碑文じゃない。……初めて見るものです。」
"The witch's epitaph, you mean? It was whispered that it pointed out the location of the hidden 10 tons of gold... ...So, Kumasawa-san tried to solve it too. But this isn't the epitaph. It's the first time I've seen it."

洋館風の扉の上にアーチがあり、そこにレリーフがある。そこに英文が刻まれていて、写真はそれを捉えたものらしい。
ペン書きは、それを訳したもののようだった。
There was an arch above the Western-style door, and that's where the relief was. English words were engraved there, and that seemed to be what the picture was focused on.

The pen writing appeared to be a translation into Japanese.

「…………………。“この扉は千兆分の一の確率でしか開かない。あなたは千兆分の一の確率でしか祝福されない”。………知らないわ。こんな文章、碑文にもお姉ちゃんの日記にも出てこない。」
".........`This door is opened only at a probability of a quadrillion to one. You will be blessed only at a probability of a quadrillion to one'. ...I don't recognize it. Nothing like this ever showed up in the epitaph or Onee-chan's diary."

「お袋の遺品の中に、碑文の謎解きに挑戦してると思われる写真やノートが、結構出てきたんですわ。
"In Mother's belongings, there were quite a few photos and notes that looked like her trying to solve the riddle of the epitaph.

お袋も案外、そういうのが好きだったんだなぁ。何でも１０ｔの金塊が隠されてたって噂だ。そりゃあ、お袋も夢中になるはずですわ。」
Mother was actually surprisingly fond of that kind of thing. And there was that rumor that 10 tons of gold bars were hidden somewhere. It's no surprise she got so absorbed by it."

真里亞お姉ちゃんの日記帳にも魔導書にも、魔女の碑文についての記載はある。
In both Maria onee-chan's diary and in her grimoire, there was a description of the witch's epitaph.

曰く、黄金郷の扉を開く儀式であり、ベアトリーチェ復活の儀式であり、ベアトリーチェ継承の儀式であり。云々。
It had talked about how it was a ceremony to open the door to the Golden Land, Beatrice's resurrection ceremony, Beatrice's succession ceremony. On and on.

興味深いのは最後の、継承の儀式、という行だったろうか。
Maybe the most interesting one was the last part, about it being a succession ceremony.

ベアトリーチェが言うには、もし魔女の碑文を解き明かすことが出来たなら、１０ｔの黄金と右代宮家の家督だけでなく、自らの魔法の力と名前、黄金の魔女の称号までもを引き継ぐという。
According to Beatrice, if you were able to solve the witch's epitaph, you would receive not only the 10 tons of gold and the Ushiromiya family inheritance, but her own magical power and name, as well as the title of Golden Witch.

魔女の碑文は、当時の右代宮家では、解けた者を次期当主に選ぶために当主金蔵が用意した難解なクイズ、という認識だった。
Among the Ushiromiya family household at the time, the witch's epitaph was thought of as a difficult quiz, which the Family Head, Kinzo, had arranged for to choose his successor.

しかしマリアージュ・ソルシエールの解釈では、その出題者はベアトリーチェ自身で、自らの後継者を選び出すための出題でもあったという。
But with the Mariage Sorcière interpretation, the questioner was Beatrice herself, and she had posed the question in part to choose her successor.

……両者の解釈は細部で微妙に食い違っている。
...There were slight discrepancies in the details of the two interpretations.

いずれにせよ、その物騒な内容は血生臭い連続殺人を想起させ、２本のボトルメッセージは双方ともそれに沿った事件を描いている。
Either way, its ominous contents brought to mind a bloody serial murder, and both of the message bottles drew a tale of a crime following that pattern.

魔女の碑文を、１２年後の今であっても解くことが出来たなら、当時の何かの陰謀を解き明かすことが、出来るのだろうか……。
If I could solve the witch's epitaph now, 12 years later, I wonder if I could expose some plot made back then...

私も何度か挑戦したが、さっぱり意味がわからなかった。
ウィッチハンターたちも大勢が挑戦しているらしい。
I tried to solve it many times myself, but I never did have a clue what it meant.

It seems that many Witch Hunters tried as well.

私の読んだ本にも、江之浦漁港説とか、ラプラタ川説とかが登場する。
しかし、いずれの説も決定的ではない……。
I also found theories like the La Plata theory and the Enoura theory in certain books.

However, neither of these theories were conclusive...

「他にも資料が？」
"Are there any other materials?"

「あると思うけど、兄弟で適当に分けたからなぁ。誰が何を持ってるやら、さっぱりですわ。申し訳ない。」
"I think so, but they were all split up between my siblings. I don't have a clue who has what. Sorry."

「………この、熊沢さんが撮影した英文だけ読むと、滅多に開かれない開かずの扉という印象を受ける。
"......Just reading this English text that Kumasawa-san took a picture of, it gives the impression that this was a forbidden door that was rarely opened.

……でもこれは屋敷の何処かしら。光の具合から、屋外みたいだけど。……熊沢さんは、この中にその黄金が隠されていると睨んでたのかしら。」
...But where in the mansion is it, I wonder? Judging by the lighting, it looks like it's outside. ...I wonder if Kumasawa-san thought that the gold might be hidden in there."

「さぁ。いずれにせよ、六軒島の屋敷のどこかでしょうな。……お袋の預金口座には、残念だが、黄金を発見したと思えるようなお金は入ってませんでしたよ。うはははは、さすがに見つからんかったんでしょうなぁ。」
"Who knows. Either way, I do wonder where in the Rokkenjima mansion it was. ...I hate to say it, but there wasn't enough money in Mother's bank account to make me think she found the gold. Uhahahaha, she probably didn't find it after all."

……１０ｔの黄金を金蔵に授けた、黄金の魔女ベアトリーチェ。
...The Golden Witch, Beatrice, gave 10 tons of gold to Kinzo.

即ち、魔女こそが黄金の真の所有者。
Which meant that the witch was the true owner of the gold.

右代宮家の莫大な財産の全ては、ベアトリーチェこそが所有者なのだ。
Beatrice was the owner of all the vast fortune of the Ushiromiya family.

その莫大な富を持つ魔女が、あの日の六軒島の人間を皆殺しにし、…戯れかのように遺族に大金を送りつける。
The witch holding this vast wealth had massacred the humans on Rokkenjima on that day, ...sending large amounts of money to the surviving relatives like it was a game.

……何が死者からの手紙だ。
これは、死者への冒涜。
...Like hell it's a letter from the dead.

This is a desecration of the dead.

私は再び確信する。
……あの日に島で死んだ家族は、死んで成仏などしていない。
I was once again convinced.

...When my family died on that island that day, they didn't go to heaven.

今も魔女に捕らわれ、永遠に冒涜されながら苛まれ続けているのだ……。
They're being trapped by the witch even now...and are being desecrated and tormented for all eternity...

縁寿が最後に訪れたのは、住宅地と小売店が混在する地域の、マルフク寝具店というを掲げた一軒の店だった……。
The last place Ange visited...was a store in the region between the housing district and the retail stores, with a signboard saying `Marufuku Sleep Shop'...

そこには、当時、六軒島への連絡船の船長をしていた男が住んでいた。
There lived the man who had been the boat captain of the ferryboat to Rokkenjima at the time.

……かつては海の男として活躍した彼も、大きな病気をして体調を崩してからは引退し、息子夫婦の家で世話になっていた…。
...Even he, who had once lived as a man of the sea, had retired after contracting a serious illness, and was now taken care of at the house of his son and his son's wife...

「よーく覚えてる…！　あんた、まだこんなに小さかった。立派になったな…！
"I remember it veeery well...! You were still about this small. Look how you've grown...!

そして、さぞや辛かっただろう。お前さんの気持ち、よくわかるぞ…！」
And...it must have been very tough on you. I know very well how you must feel...!"

元船長は、引退の理由が何だったかよくわからないくらいに元気だった。
The former boat captain was in such high spirits that you couldn't really tell why he had retired in the first place.

記憶も鮮明らしく、１０年以上前のことをよく覚えており、当時の縁寿のことさえも記憶しているようだった。
His memory seemed clear too, and he could remember the events of more than a decade ago well, apparently even about how Ange had been at the time.

話が弾み、縁寿としてはとても助かったが、……同時に、最後の親族会議のこともよく覚えていて、船上の戦人の“落ちる落ちる騒ぎ”のことまでも詳細に記憶していたことは、逆に縁寿には辛かった。
The way he chatted on was very helpful for Ange, ...but at the same time, he also remembered the final family conference very well, and the fact that he remembered even details like Battler's `fall fall madness' on the boat was actually painful for her.

当時もだが、現在も六軒島に渡る公的移動手段は存在しない。
渡航には、船の所有者に個人的に頼む必要があった。
It had been so back then as well, but even now, there was no public way to cross to Rokkenjima.

It was necessary to make an individual request to an owner of a boat to make the voyage.

六軒島への船は今だ手配が出来ず、彼に断られたら、六軒島への渡航はもはや絶望的と思われた……。
I'd been unable to arrange for a boat to Rokkenjima, so if he refused me, such a voyage would probably become hopeless...

「わかってる。今、あの島に行きたがる船なんぞ、簡単には見つからんだろ。
"I getcha. It won't be easy to find a boat eager to go to that island.

……今じゃ六軒島と呼ばず、古い名前の悪食島と呼ぶ者までおる。この辺りの船乗りじゃ、首を縦には振るまいな。」
...By now, there are even some who call it by its old name, Akujikishima, instead of Rokkenjima. It's understandable why the sailors around here would turn down your request."

元々、漁民たちの間では六軒島は不吉の島と恐れられていた。
そして、１２年前のあの事件で、それは頂点に達した……。
From the start, fishermen had feared Rokkenjima as an island of misfortune.

And because of that incident 12 years ago, this fear had reached a peak...

彼らは海を尊敬し、畏怖し、そして信心深い。
呪われた島に船を出そうとする船乗りはほとんどいなかった。
They respected the sea, feared it, and revered it.

There were almost no sailors who would try to take a boat to the cursed island.

その為、ウィッチハンターの多くは六軒島へ渡ることが出来ず、せいぜい、島の周りを周遊するのが限界だった。
Because of that, most of the Witch Hunters were unable to cross over to Rokkenjima...and were limited to taking a trip around the island.

……皮肉にも、そのせいでますますに六軒島の神秘性が増し、彼らが喜ぶようなおかしな魔女話が増殖する結果となるのだが…。
...Ironically, this had caused the sense of mystery surrounding Rokkenjima to increase even more, which had resulted in the propagation of the bizarre witch stories they loved so much...

「………船は、出してもらえるでしょうか。」
"......Would you take me in your boat?"

「うむ。
"Yep.

明日だけ返してもらう約束になっとる。最近はエンジンがだいぶご機嫌斜めらしいがな。かっ飛ばしてやるわい！」
They're supposed to give it back to me just for tomorrow. Though it seems its engine has been in a pretty bad mood lately. I'll knock it into shape!"

元船長は、明日、前職に復帰し、六軒島まで船を出してくれることを約束してくれた。
The former boat captain promised that tomorrow, he would go back to his previous job and take his boat out to Rokkenjima.

これで、六軒島への渡航手段は確保できた。
新島で出来ることは、これで全てだろう。
Now, my method of transport to Rokkenjima is ensured.

This is probably all I can do on Niijima.

あとは、明日。
All that's left...is tomorrow.

六軒島で、……１２年前に遡る旅は、終点を迎える。
On Rokkenjima, ...I'll reach the final destination of a journey that stretches back 12 years.

『よかったね…。これで島へ行けるようになったね…。』
『Isn't that great...? This way, it looks like you'll be able to go to the island...』

「そうね。……船を見つけるのは難しいと聞いていたから、船長が協力的で助かったわ。」
"It sure does. ...I'd heard that it would be hard to find a boat, so the boat captain's helpfulness really saved me."

「………縁寿さまほどではないにしても。船長にとっても１２年前の事件は、未だ抜けない棘なんでしょうね。」
"......Although it may not be the same as it was for you, Ange-sama, I'm sure the incident 12 years ago has been a thorn for the boat captain as well, one that he still hasn't been able to pull out."

『……うりゅ。……船長さんも、心の整理がつかなかったんだね。ずっと。』
『...Uryu. ...Even the boat captain wasn't able to sort out his feelings. This whole time...』

「そりゃそうでしょ。……約束通り１０月５日に、あのじいさんが船を出してくれれば、大勢が助かった可能性がある。
"That's probably true. ...If that guy had taken his boat out on October 5 as promised, there's a chance that he could've saved a lot of people.

ちょっと風が強いからといって、船を渋らなければ…。」
If he hadn't been hesitant to go out just because of a little wind..."

『うりゅ…、そんなこと言っちゃ駄目だよ…。船長さんもそれを今日まで、ずっと苦しんできたはずだよ……。』
『Uryu, ...you shouldn't say things like that... I'm sure that's pained the boat captain constantly until today...』

１０月５日は、まさに台風の真っ只中だったそうだ。
Apparently, they truly had been right in the middle of a typhoon on October 5.

船長に言わせると、１０月４日に六軒島へ向かえば、確実に台風に閉じ込められることはわかっていたという。
According to the boat captain, he had known for certain that they'd be trapped by the typhoon if they headed to Rokkenjima on October 4.

しかし彼らは、予め決定された親族会議の日付に強く固執した。
But the family had been very persistent about the date of their conference, which had been determined beforehand.

……無理もない。親族の誰もが過密なスケジュールを持ち、予め日程を調整した上で親族会議に訪れている。
...It was only natural. All of the relatives had been very busy at the time, and they came to the family conference only after arranging their schedules beforehand.

台風が近付いているから翌週に変更、と簡単には言えない事情もあっただろう。
It was probably a situation where they couldn't easily push it back to the next week just because a typhoon was approaching.

……船長の責任ではない。
...It wasn't the boat captain's fault.

しかし、台風のせいにしてしまえるほど、彼は無責任ではなかった、ということかもしれない。
But perhaps you could say that he wasn't so irresponsible that he could place the blame wholly on the typhoon.

確かに船長はマモンたちの言うとおり、ずっと１２年前を引き摺ってきたに違いない。
Certainly, just as these two said, there's no doubt that the boat captain has been dragging the events of 12 years ago along with him this whole time.

……そして、最後の右代宮一族である私を島に送り届け、それを無事に連れ帰ることで、過去に決着をつけようとしているのかもしれない…。
...And, by taking me, the last member of the Ushiromiya line, to the island, and bringing me back safely, he might be trying to find some resolution for his past...

「船は昼過ぎに帰ってくることになってる。それからあんたを六軒島へ案内するから、到着は夕方前になるだろう。
"The boat is supposed to return just after noon. I'll guide you to Rokkenjima after that, so we should arrive before evening.

電気も灯りもない島だ。あまり長居は出来んぞ。……その程度の上陸で、あんたの気は済むかね？」
It's an island without electricity or lights. You won't be able to stay long. ...Will you be satisfied with a landing that short?"

「…………………。
"......

長居したから何かの気が済む、というものでもありませんし。船を出してもらえるだけでも感謝します。」
There's nothing that would make me more satisfied by staying longer. I'm grateful just to have you take me there."

「うむ、すまんな。わしが船を手放していなければ、ケチなことを言わず、好きなだけ島へ案内してやれるんだが…。」
"Yep, don't mention it. If I hadn't parted with my boat, I'd be able to guide you to the island as much as you liked, without being stingy..."

六軒島で何かをしたいという目的があるわけじゃない。
It's not like I have a goal of doing something in particular on Rokkenjima.

滞在する時間帯は、夕方頃か…。
So, I'll be there during the evening...

……昼と夜という異なる世界を跨ぐ夕方は、まるでこの世とあの世、もしくは、１９９８年と１９８６年の境目のような気がして、六軒島を訪れる時間としてもっとも相応しいようにも感じられた。
...The evening, which straddles the two different worlds of day and night, seemed almost like a borderline between this world and the next...or possibly, 1998 and 1986, and it felt like the most fitting time to visit Rokkenjima.

……島で何かをするわけじゃない。
...It's not like I have anything in particular to do there.

ほんの数時間の滞在でも、私の心の整理がつくならば充分だろう。
Just staying there for a few hours should be enough for me to find some closure.

その時、障子が小さくノックされ、天草が顔を出し、腕時計を叩くような仕草をする。
私も頷き返し、明日の船は確保できたことを教えた。
At that time, there was a small knock on the paper sliding door, and Amakusa stuck his head in, tapping his watch.

I nodded back and told him about how I had succeeded in reserving a boat for tomorrow.

「それは良かった。……そろそろ参りましょう。
"That's great. ...It's about time for us to go.

船長、明日はよろしくお願いします。」
We'll be counting on you tomorrow, Captain."

「おう、任せておけ！　お前さんたちの難儀な事情も聞いとる。わしも、当時のワイドショーを見ていて、面白半分に事件を掻き回す連中に虫唾が走っとったもんだ。協力は惜しまんよ。」
"Sure, leave it to me! I've heard all about what you guys've gone through. I also watched the talk shows at the time...and was disgusted by the people who stirred up that incident just for fun. I'll help out any way I can."

「ありがとうございます。……それでは明日、お昼に。
"Thank you very much. ...Then we'll see you noon tomorrow.

あの、これ。船代に。」
Umm, here. The fare for the boat."

縁寿は懐より帯封付きの壱万円札の束を取り出す。
Ange took a wrapped wad of ten-thousand yen bills from her pocket.

その厚みは、確かに船長にも見えたはずだ。しかし船長はまったく興味を示さず、首を横に振った。
The boat captain should have noticed its thickness as well, but he paid it absolutely no interest and shook his head.

「……わしはお前さんに感謝しとるよ。これは天のお導きだ。あんたを、六軒島へ連れて行き、そして無事に連れ帰る最後のチャンスを下さったんだ。わしは金蔵さんに任されていた最後の仕事を、今、ようやく終えることが出来る。だからあんたには感謝してる。カネは、当時の金蔵さんからたらふくもらってる。あんたから取れんよ。」
"...I'm grateful to you. This is a sign from the heavens. I've been given a final chance to take you to Rokkenjima and bring you back safely. Now, I'll finally be able to finish the final job Kinzo-san entrusted me with. So I'm grateful to you. I got more than enough money from Kinzo-san back then. I can't accept yours."

「…………………ありがとうございます。」
".........Thank you very much."

「階段、足元に気をつけてな。急だぞ。」
"Watch your step on the stairs. It's steep."

……バリアフリーという言葉と確実に対極にある、急勾配の階段を下る。
...I went down the steep staircase that was the exact opposite of `accessible'.

上の部屋にあった、テレビやタンスの存在が信じられなくなる。
It was getting hard to believe that there was actually a chest of drawers and a TV in the room upstairs.

一階の大部分は寝具店の店舗となっていて、たくさんの布団が山と積み上げられていた。
その狭い布団売り場を抜け、見送ってもらう。
Most of the first floor was a bedding store, with many futons piled up on each other.

We weaved our way through the cramped futon shop.

天草は用心深く表の様子をうかがってから先に飛び出し、車を回してくる。
After cautiously checking around outside, Amakusa dashed out first and started up the car.

「孫の部屋が空いとる。泊まっていっても構わんのに。見ての通り、布団なら有り余っとるぞ。」
"My grandchild's room is empty. I really wouldn't mind if you stayed there. As you see, we've got plenty of extra futons."

「ありがとうございます。
"Thanks a lot for the offer.

……万一の時、ご迷惑は掛けられませんので。」
...But this way, even if the unexpected happens, you won't be bothered."

「………事情は知らんが、相当な厄介に巻き込まれてるようだな。胡散臭い連中が、人探しをしていると噂になっとる。あんたのことじゃないのかね？」
"......I don't know the details, but it seems you've been caught up in a lot of trouble. There's a rumor that some suspicious people are searching for someone. That wouldn't happen to be you, would it?"

「…………………。……さぁ。」
"............Who knows."

縁寿はとぼけるが、船長は察してくれているようだった。
Ange played dumb, but it looked as though the boat captain had guessed.

「わしは、六軒島を目指す客人を送り届け、……そして迎えに行き、連れ帰ることが仕事だった。
"My job is to take guests to Rokkenjima...and bring them back again.

……その仕事を１２年前に中断したまま、まだ終えていない。だからわしは、あんたのお陰でその仕事を、ようやく終えることが出来るんだ。」
...That job was put on hold 12 years ago, and it still hasn't ended. So, thanks to you, I'll finally be able to finish it."

「…………………。」
"........."

「だから。………わしにその仕事を終えさせてくれよ？　わかってるな？」
"So listen. ......Let me finish this job, okay? Do you understand me?"

「………………。
".........

……えぇ。別に私は、死にに行くんじゃない。」
...Yeah. It's not like I'm going there to die."

でも、あの島で死ねたなら、きっと家族のところへ行けるだろうという気持ちは、ある……。
But part of me does feel that, if I could die on that island, I'd surely be able to go to where my family is...

私もようやく自覚した。
……私はひょっとしたら、あの島で、……死ぬつもりだったのかもしれない。
I've finally become aware of it.

...I might have been planning...to die on that island.

死に場所を求めて遥々と、六軒島を目指して来たのかもしれないのだ。
I might have come all this way, heading towards Rokkenjima, in search of a place to die.

それを船長も察している。
だからこそ、死ぬなと重ねて言う。
The boat captain had guessed that as well.

That's why he repeatedly told me not to die.

「………えぇ、死にません。約束します。
"......Yeah, I won't die. I promise.

………そもそも私。どうして六軒島に行かなくてはならないかの目的さえ、未だにあやふやなんですから。」
......After all, I'm still not sure if there's any reason why I need to go to Rokkenjima."

「いいや、目的はきっとある。
"No, I'm sure there's a reason.

あんたにないなら、…それは~ib~彼ら~ib~にあるんだ。
Even if there isn't one for you, ...there is one for ~ib~them~ib~.

島があんたを呼んだ。だからあんたはここまで来たんだ。」
The island called you. That's why you came here."

「………そうかも、知れませんね。…私は、……呼ばれたのかもしれない。」
"......That might...be true. ...I might...have been called."

呼ばれた。何のために？　彼らのために。
お父さん。お母さん。戦人お兄ちゃん。
I was called. For what reason? For them.

Father. Mother. Battler onii-chan.

……そして、真里亞お姉ちゃん。
...And, Maria onee-chan.

………あるいは、黄金の魔女。
ベアトリーチェ。
......Or maybe, the Golden Witch.

Beatrice.

六軒島で、何があるんだろう。
そして私は何を成すんだろう。
What is on Rokkenjima?

And what will I achieve?

いよいよ明日を控えているのに、私は未だに自らの使命を理解できていなかった……。
Even though tomorrow is finally almost here, I still haven't been able to understand my own mission...

店の前に車が止まる音がして、短いクラクションが聞こえた。
There was the sound of a car stopping in front of the store, and a short honk could be heard.

「それでは明日。失礼します…。」
"Then I'll see you tomorrow. If you'll excuse me..."

「うむ。」
"Yep."

狭い店内の布団の山を抜け、私は店を出ようとする。
Winding between the stacks of futons in the cramped store, I was about to go outside.

…………その時、足が止まった。
......Then, my feet stopped.

「……どうしたね？」
"...What is it?"

「………………………あ、
……………あの、
あれは……？」
".........U-

Umm,

...what is that...?"




「うん？　あれ？　はて？　何の話だね？」
"Hmm? That? What? What are you talking about?"

私はわなわなと震えながら、………それを指差す。
Trembling all over, ......I pointed at it.

しかし船長はいくら目を凝らしても、私が驚くような何が指の先にあるのか、さっぱり理解できなかった。
But no matter how much the boat captain squinted, he noticed absolutely nothing in that direction that should have surprised me.

……そんなことって、…………そ、……そんなことって…………。
...That must mean, ......th-that must mean......

「…………あ、ありえない……。…ど、どうして…………？」
"......I-Impossible... ...Wh-Why......?"

『う、………うりゅ………。……縁寿、
……どうして？　どういうことなのこれは……？！』
『...U-Uryu...... ...Ange,

...what does it mean? What's going on here...?!』

「……わ、………私にだってさっぱりだわ……。そんな馬鹿なことってあるの……。
"...I-I don't have a clue either... There's no way something that ridiculous...

これは魔法なの？　奇跡なの……？
Is this magic? A miracle...?"

………えぇ、多分これは運命よ。……私は今、……理解したわ。…………これが、……私の使命だったのよ。」
"......Yes, this is probably fate. ...Now, ...I understand. ......This was...my mission."

『…………うりゅ……………。』
『......Uryu.........』

「私には、………何が何だか…………。」
"I......don't have a clue what......"

私は震えながら、店内の薄暗がりを指差し、固まっている……。
Shaking, I pointed into the thin darkness inside the store...and froze up...

「ど、どうしたんだね？　何があるんだね？！　わからん、…わしにはわからん…。あ、あんたには何が見えてるのかね…？！」
"Wh-What is it? You see something there, don't you?! I don't...I don't see anything... Wh-What is it you see...?!"

「ありがとう、船長。
"Thank you, Captain.

……全部全部、
……これは運命だったんです。ここに私が訪れることさえ、
……運命だった。…………これが、
………私が六軒島へ行く、目的で、使命なんです………。」
...Everything, everything...

...was fate. Even me visiting this place...

...was fate. ......This is...

...the mission...and the purpose...that I'm going to Rokkenjima for......"




「…………縁寿さん？
"......Ange-san?

どうしました、トラブルですか？」
What is it, is something wrong?"

「わ、わしにもさっぱりわからん…！　お嬢ちゃんが暗がりを指差したまま、固まっちまったんだ…！」
"I-I don't have a clue either...! This girl just froze up while pointing into the darkness...!"

「縁寿さん……？　大丈夫ですか？　何が見えるんですか……？」
"Ange-san...? Are you okay? What can you see...?"

「あなたたちには見えないの？　それよ、それ。
"Can't you two see it? It's that, right there.

……見えないの？！」
...Can't you see it?!"

「見えるのは、ただの陳列棚です。誰もいやしませんぜ…？」
"All I can see is a normal display case. There's no one there, right...?"

『うりゅ……、……縁寿……。……ボクには何が何だかわからないよ……。
『Uryu , ...Ange, ...I don't know what's going on...

……これは、……夢なの？　魔法なの……？　どういうことなの……？　……………？　…………縁寿……………？』
...Is this...a dream? Magic...? What is it...? ......? ......Ange......?』

さくたろうが、縁寿の顔を見上げる……。
Sakutarou lifted his face towards Ange...

　その瞳から、
……ぼろりと、
……一筋の涙が零れ落ちる。
From his eyes,

...slid a single tear.




「………縁寿さま………………。」

...And,

This is......magic, isn't it......?

「………テストって……？」
"......A test...?"

「……う、うむ。よく聞きなさい……。」
"...Y-Yes. Listen well..."

再びゲストハウスに蔵臼たちから電話が掛かってきた。
Once again, there was a call from Krauss to the guesthouse.

……そして告げられたのは、……金蔵が孫たちに、次期当主の資格を問うテストを行ないたい、とするものだった。
...And the message was...that Kinzo wanted to hold a test to see if the grandchildren had the qualifications to become his successor.

「………当主様は次期当主を、お父さんたちの兄弟からではなく、孫たちの中から選びたいと、そう、……仰っている…。」
"......The Head has said that his successor will not be one of us siblings... That he wants...to pick from among his grandchildren..."

蔵臼の抑圧されたしゃべり方から、娘である朱志香は、そう話すよう強要されていることを理解する。
From Krauss's restrained style of speech, Jessica realized as his daughter that he was being forced to speak.

そして、父親たち人質は今も危険に晒されていて、テストとやらを断れば、人質に危害が加えられる可能性があることまでも理解せざるを得なかった。
And she was forced to realize that the hostages were being exposed to danger even now, and that if they refused this test, there was a possibility that the hostages would be harmed.

「そ、……それで……。私たちは、どうすればいいの。」
"Th-Then, ......what should we do?"

「……う、…うむ。待て…。」
"...I-Indeed. Hold on..."

蔵臼は受話器を離し、鉄格子の向こうでにやにやと見ている金蔵を見る。
そして金蔵は次なる連絡を命じた。
Krauss put down the receiver, then looked at the grinning Kinzo on the other side of the bars.

Kinzo gave his next order.

「テストの前に、無関係な者を排除しなくてはならない。
"Before the test, those not involved must be removed.

………郷田と熊沢がそこにいるのであろう？　テストに干渉されては邪魔なのでな。彼らをゲストハウスより追放せよ。」
......Gohda and Kumasawa are there, I believe? It will be a problem if they interfere with the test. Banish them from the guesthouse."

「………追放、…ですか……。」
"......Banish, ...you say...?"

「薔薇庭園に園芸倉庫があったはず。そこへ郷田と熊沢を閉じ込めて施錠せよ。
"There should be a gardening storehouse in the rose garden. Lock Gohda and Kumasawa in there.

ふむ、まずはそれからだ。直ちに遂行するように伝えよ。………我が武具たちが監視する。疑わしい行為に及べば、テストは直ちに中止し、お前たち全てを生贄として処刑する！」
Hmm, we'll begin from there. Tell them to do it immediately. ......My weapons will be watching. If they happen to do anything questionable, I'll instantly stop the test and execute all of you as sacrifices!"

「……わ、……わかりました……。
"...I-I understand...

……もしもし朱志香…。今から父さんの言うことをよく聞きなさい……。」
...Hello, Jessica...? Listen closely to what I say..."

蔵臼は朱志香に、郷田と熊沢を閉じ込めるようにとの指示を伝える……。
Krauss relayed the orders to lock up Gohda and Kumasawa...

"...What kind of test are you planning?"

"Hmm? Aah, it truly is a simple test. I only want my grandchildren to show me their resolve. Well then, I wonder what kind of results they'll show me. ...*cackle*."

霧江は、子どもたちに電話している蔵臼を苦々しそうに見ている。
Looking disgusted, Kyrie watched Krauss, who was talking with the children.

……悔しいが、今は命令を拒むことが出来ない。
...I hate it, but for now, we cannot refuse orders.

この地下牢での小さな反抗は何の意味も持たない。
In this dungeon, a feeble resistance won't amount to anything.

下手に挑発し、自分たちを殺させるような事態に追い込んでしまったら、もう殺人鬼に歯止めなど効かない。
If we provoke him too much and drive him into a position where he might kill us, there will no longer be any way to stop this murderer.

……彼のルールにとりあえず従い、興奮させないようにしながら、チャンスを待つしかないのだ……。
...For now, the only choice left is to obey his rules without agitating him, ...all the while waiting for an opportunity...

しかし、金蔵の命令に従順に従い続ければ、テストと称する何かに子どもたちは襲われ、命を失うことさえあるかもしれない。
However, if we continue to obediently follow his commands, the children might be attacked in this so-called test, and they might even lose their lives.

………従順を装おうとも、反抗しようとも、……状況を改善できないのだ。
......Whether we feign obedience or try to resist, ...nothing will cause the situation to improve.

とにかく、最後の一瞬までチャンスを見逃さないよう、目を凝らしていることだけが、今できる抵抗なのだ。
Anyway, straining our eyes so that we don't let a single chance escape until the very end...is the only resistance possible now.

……霧江はそう自らに言い聞かしながら、金蔵の命令を伝えている蔵臼を見守るのだった……。
...While telling herself this, Kyrie watched over Krauss as he delivered Kinzo's orders...

「………霧江さん。ここは、辛抱しましょう……。」
"......Kyrie-san, let us be patient..."

「わかってるわ。……悔しいけれど、今は待つしかない。
"I understand. ...It's unfortunate, but all we can do right now is wait.

この鉄格子さえ何とかできれば、私たちは屋敷へ戻ることができるんだから……。」
If only we could do something about these bars, we'd be able to return to the mansion..."

「……何とかここを出られれば……。……た、試して見ましょう。
"...If only we could somehow get out of here... ...I-I'll try something.

……………金蔵さん、頼みがある。」
.........Kinzo-san, I have a request."

「む、何か、我が友よ。」
"Hmm, what is it, my friend?"

「金蔵さんが子どもたちを試したいというのはよくわかった…。……金蔵さんの納得の行くようにするといい。
"We understand well that you want to test the children... ...It is fine for you to do as you desire."

金蔵さんの力がなければ、とっくに潰れていたかもしれない右代宮家だ。その担い手を慎重に選びたい気持ち、よぉくわかる…。それに、その為の親族会議だ。私らは邪魔はせんよ…。」
"Without your power, the Ushiromiya family might have been destroyed long ago. We truly understand why you want to carefully select the person who will take charge. Besides, that is what the family conference is all about. We won't get in your way..."

「ふむ。お前の理解が得られて助かる。そうだ、これは親族会議なのだ。私が次期当主を選び決定する、最後の親族会議なのだよ。ふっはっはっははははは…！」
"Hmm. Your insight is useful. That's right, this is the family conference. The final family conference, where I will select my successor. Fuhahahaha...!"

「それでだが金蔵さん…。……ここはあまりに冷え過ぎる。あんたのテストの邪魔はせんから、もう少し温かい場所に移してもらうことは出来んかね……。」
"And yet, Kinzo-san, ...it is far too cold here. Since we won't interfere with your test, couldn't you take us to a slightly warmer place...?"

「………………。」
"........."

南條のその一言で、金蔵のわずかにだけ機嫌を良くしたかに感じられた気配が、吹き飛ぶ。
At Nanjo's words, the slight signs that Kinzo's mood had been improving were blown away.

値踏みするような険しい目で睨みつける沈黙が、南條にぶつけられる……。
Nanjo was struck with a moment of silence as Kinzo gazed at him with dangerous eyes, as though appraising him...

「……確かにここは冷えますね。老体にはお辛いでしょう。
"...Certainly, this place is cold. It's tough on an old body.

……お館様。上の部屋に移し変えても良いのでは……。」
...Master, wouldn't it be all right if we moved them upstairs...?"

「それは出来ぬッ！！　甘いぞ、南條ぉおおおぉ…？　お前は一手猶予を与えるような素振りで、実に華麗に布石を打つではないか。その手には乗らんぞぉぉお…？　凍えるというなら、真っ赤に焼けた石炭でも敷き詰めてやればよいッ！！」
"I cannot do that!! Are you naive, Nanjoooooo...? So, by acting as though you'll skip this turn, you truly and splendidly advance your strategy? I'm not falling for that, you seeeee...? If you're freezing, then why don't I line the floor with red hot coals!!"

「も、申し訳ございません……。」
"M-My apologies..."

ワルギリアも助け舟を出してくれたが、結局、金蔵が聞き入れることはなかった…。
Virgilia had tried to help out, but in the end, Kinzo would not comply...

「……………あなたたちは大人しいのね。…その気になれば、こんな鉄格子、簡単に破れるでしょうに。」
".........You two sure are obedient. ...If you felt like it, you could easily break these bars."

「………………………。」
"..............."

「……ここを破ったとて、何もなりません。」
"...Even if we break them, nothing will come of it."

「確かに。……ここを破ったなら、ゴールドスミスのゲームが終わることを意味する。……あなたたちも、そしてゲストハウスの人間たちも即座に、金蔵の儀式の生贄となるでしょうね。
"Of course. ...If you were to break these, it would mean the end of Goldsmith's game. ...All of you, as well as those humans in the guesthouse, would immediately become sacrifices for Kinzo's ceremony."

……でも、案外、あなたたちだけかもしれないわよ？　この状況を打開できる力を持っているのは、……ね？
"...But, surprisingly, you two might be the only ones, yes? Perhaps only you two hold the power to break out of this situation, ...right?"

………黄金郷に辿り着きたいんでしょう？　叶えたい夢がいっぱいあるんでしょう…？　くすくす……。」
"......You want to reach the Golden Land, don't you? You must have many dreams you want granted, right...? *cackle*cackle*..."

「…………………………。」
"..............."

「ガァプ。挑発はいけませんよ。
"Gaap, you musn't provoke them.

……これはあなたのゲームではない。お館様の、そしてお嬢様のゲームです。」
...This is not your game. It is the Master's, as well as Milady's game."

「………どうした、ロノウェ？」
"......What is it, Ronove?"

「いえいえ、何も。
"Oh, no, nothing.

……捕虜とおしゃべりをしていました。お許しを。」
...We were talking to the prisoners. Forgive us."

ガァプは最後に、挑発的な笑みを嘉音に送ると、背を向けた。
嘉音は下唇を噛みながら、両拳を震わせるしかない……。
Gaap sent one final sneering smile at Kanon, then turned away.

Kanon could only bite his lower lip and shake his fists...

「…………………。……くそ………。」
"............ ...Dammit......"

「……よくがんばったね……。よく我慢したよ……。」
"...You did well... Good job hanging in there..."

「僕たちは、無力だ……。家具だから……。」
"We're powerless... Because we're furniture..."

「そうだね、……私たちは無力。
"That's right, ...we're powerless.

……でも、家具は、必要とされることだって、…そして愛されることだってあるよ。……今の私たちは、暗い地下室にしまわれているだけ。
...However, furniture is sometimes relied upon...and even loved. ...Right now, we've only been stored away in the basement.

……きっといつか、誰かが愛してくれる。必要としてくれるから。……だから今は挑発に乗らないで、堪えよう…。……ね？」
...Surely, one day, somebody will love us. Because they'll rely on us. ...That's why, for now, let's ignore their provocation and bear with it... ...Okay?"

「……お父さん。郷田たちを倉庫に閉じ込めるよう、指示をしました。」
"...Father, I've ordered them to lock up Gohda and Kumasawa in the storehouse."

「良かろう。電話を切って良い。
"Very well. Hang up now.

……シエスタ姉妹。孫たちが郷田と熊沢を閉じ込めるのを監視せよ。もしも不審な動きがあるようならば、……その時点で次期当主を選ぶテストは終了だ。」
...Chiester Sisters, observe the grandchildren as they lock Gohda and Kumasawa away. If they do anything suspicious, ...then in that moment, the selection test for my successor will be over."

金蔵が命じると、シエスタ姉妹が背後に整列して現れる。
When Kinzo made his order, the Chiester Sisters appeared behind him in a line.

「了解であります。……斥候は私がやる。５５６と４１０は両翼支援。４５は全周警戒。」
"Understood, sir. ...I will scout. 556 and 410 will cover both flanks. 45, you're on wide-area surveillance."

「００…。５５６は……。」
"00, 556 is..."

「ん、…………そうだった。すまない。」
"Ah, ......that's right. Sorry."

「いい子でした……。」
"She was a good kid..."

「……だから私は嫌いにぇ。…いいヤツは。」
"...That's why I don't like them nyeh. ...Good people."

「何をしているか、シエスタ姉妹！　我が命令を遂行せよ！」
"What are you doing, Chiester Sisters?! Follow my orders!"

「……………失礼しました。では、監視に向かうであります。……出撃！」
"......My apologies, sir. Then, let us go observe. ...Move out!"

シエスタ姉妹たちは一斉に姿を消す。
The Chiester Sisters erased their forms simultaneously.

その、瞬間移動のように姿を現し、そして姿を消す瞬間を南條と霧江は目撃していたが、暗がりより現れ、暗がりに姿を消したため、瞬間移動のように見えてしまったのだろうと解釈し、目をごしごしと擦ることしか出来なかった…。
Nanjo and Kyrie had witnessed the instants they appeared and disappeared as if by teleportation, but they interpreted this as moving in and out of the darkness in a way that only looked like teleportation, and the two could do nothing but rub their eyes...

「……さて。私はテストの準備をしよう。ロノウェ、ガァプ。お前たちには試験官を頼む。
"...Well then, I shall begin the preparations for the test. Ronove, Gaap, I'm asking you to be the examiners.

ワルギリアはこやつらを監視するように。………何しろ我が家具が２人いる。一応は警戒せよ。」
Virgilia, you'll watch these rats. ......After all, two of my furniture are here. Just in case, be on your guard."

じろりと紗音と嘉音を見る。
紗音は硬く目を瞑りながら黙礼し、余計なことはしませんと無言で答えた……。
He glanced at Shannon and Kanon.

Tightly closing her eyes, Shannon gave a silent bow and answered wordlessly, avoiding any unnecessary actions...

「……かしこまりました。注意します。」
"...Certainly. I'll be careful."

「リーアの老体には寒くて辛くない？　湯たんぽでも持ってくる…？」
"Isn't this cold hard on your old body, Lia? Should I bring you a hot water bottle...?"

「うるさいです。早くお行きなさい。ガプっ。」
"Shut up. Go quickly. Gap!"




「ぷっくっくっく…！　さてさて、テストとは、そして試験官とは、今回のゲームは変わった試みですね。
"Pukukuku...! Well now, what a strange experience this game is, to have a test and examiners.

………お嬢様を楽しませる展開になると良いのですが。」
......I do hope this development entertains Milady."

「……さぁさお出でなさい、山羊の従者たち。」
"...Come, arise, goat attendants."

ワルギリアが暗がりに呼び掛けると、そこより、ぬうっと、山羊頭の大柄な従者が３人現れる。
Virgilia began to call out into the darkness, and from that spot, three massive goat-headed attendants suddenly appeared.

「ベアトの眷属ね。便利だわ。しかも温かそうだし。
"Ah, Beato's minions. How convenient. Plus, they seem so warm.

あぁ、湯たんぽの代わりね。なら山羊より羊の方がいいんじゃない？」
I see, so you'll use them instead of a hot water bottle. In that case, wouldn't sheep have been better than goats?"

「カシミア雑巾のくせにうるさいですよ。……彼らは賢くはありませんが、命令に忠実で強靭な頼れる従者たちです。」
"You're the one wearing cashmere. ...They aren't very bright, but they faithfully follow orders and are quite dependable."

「うむ、任せるぞ。我が友、ワルギリアよ。
"Indeed, I leave it to you, my friend, Virgilia.

……残りの者は私と来い。」
...The rest of you, follow me."

金蔵は貫禄ある仕草でマントを翻す。
With a dignified gesture, Kinzo fluttered his cloak.

その後に、ロノウェとガァプも続き、
Following him were Ronove and Gaap,

……召喚されたばかりの３人の山羊の従者までも続いていこうとする。
...as well as the three recently summoned goat attendants.

「……あなたたちは私と残るのですよ。ついていかないように。」
"...Hey, you three are supposed to wait here with me. Don't follow them."

ビクっと驚いて立ち止まり、とぼとぼと戻ってくる山羊たち。
The goats jumped in surprise and then came tottering back.

そのやり取りに、呆然と見ていた霧江もさすがに噴出す。
Kyrie, who had been watching stunned as all of this played out, couldn't help but snort.

「くっくっく……。愉快な部下ね。」
"Heheh... What entertaining underlings."

「ゴ、ゴールドスミス卿より、私語の許可は与えられていませんよ。」
"L-Lord Goldsmith did not give you permission to speak."

…多少は恥ずかしかったのだろう。
...She was probably embarrassed.

ワルギリアは冷たそうにそう言い放つが、霧江にはそれが見え見えで、しばらくの間、くぐもった笑いを抑えられずにいるのだった。
Virgilia had spoken cooly, but Kyrie saw through that, and for a little while, she couldn't restrain her muffled laughter.

しかし内心は、一体、金蔵には何人の仲間がいるのかと驚いていた。
However, on the inside, Kyrie was surprised at the number of people Kinzo had with him.

少なくとも、金蔵を含めて、すでに１０人もの敵を目撃しているのだから…。
After all, including Kinzo himself, at least 10 enemies had already been spotted...

……今、自分たちが閉じ込められている地下牢は、九羽鳥庵という秘密の屋敷の地下だという。
...The dungeon they were currently locked in was supposedly underneath the hidden mansion called Kuwadorian.

この屋敷の存在は、囁かれながらも、今日まで蔵臼さえも知らなかった。
Although this mansion had been whispered of, not even Krauss had known of its existence until today.

そんな風な、金蔵以外に知らない施設がいくつも六軒島には存在し、金蔵しか知らない、未知の手下が何人も潜んでいたというのだろうか…？
Are there actually several facilities like this on Rokkenjima, where many unknown henchmen that only Kinzo knows of hide...?

一体、この台風で閉ざされた六軒島には、今、何人の人間がいるというのか…？
Just how many humans are on Rokkenjima, locked away by the typhoon...?

いや、むしろ。
この島にいる人数は１８人なんて思い込んでいるのは、自分たちだけなのではないか……？
No, on the contrary...

Were we the only ones under the impression that there were only 18 people on this island...?

ベアトリーチェはいるのか、いないのか、などと悩み、１９人目の存在程度で頭を悩ませていた自分たちは、この島ではまさに井の中の蛙ではないのか…？
Were we, who bickered over whether Beatrice existed or not and worried about whether a 19 person existed or not, nothing more than the frogs in a well on this island...?

いやいや、それどころか…。今や、敵の方がこちらよりも人数が多いのではないか…？
No wait, not only that... By now, are there actually more people on the enemy's side than on ours...?

「…………何が起こってるの、一体……。魔女？　悪魔？　魔法？　……それを信じろというの？　おかしいのは私の目？　それとも頭なの？　…頭がどうにかなりそうよ………。」
"......Just what the hell is going on...? Witches? Demons? Magic? ...Are you telling us to believe in those? Are my eyes screwed up? Or is it my head? ...I think I'm losing it......"

魔法にて繰り広げる大虐殺。
宙より姿を現し、宙に消える悪魔たち。
A mass murder by magic.

Demons forming and disappearing into thin air.

敵の人数がどうこうよりも、目の当たりにさせられている数々の、この世の常識では説明できない現象を、どう解釈すればいいというのか。
Setting aside the enemy's numbers, how should we interpret the various things thrust before our eyes that cannot be explained with the common sense of our world?

……霧江は何が何だかわからなくなり、全てを投げ出して降参したくなる気持ちと必死に戦いながら、正気を保とうと歯を食いしばるのだった…。
...Kyrie started to feel like she didn't know what was going on anymore, and while desperately battling the urge to abandon everything and give up, she grit her teeth and tried to hold onto her sanity...

当然だが、郷田も熊沢も、薔薇庭園の園芸倉庫に閉じ込められるなど、まっぴらごめんだった。
Obviously, Gohda and Kumasawa were quite unwilling to be locked in the rose garden shed.

……しかし逆らえば、人質たちの安全は保証されないと脅されている…。
...But they were threatened that, if they resisted, the hostages' safety could not be guaranteed...

彼らはなかなか納得してくれなかったが、園芸倉庫に閉じ込めた後、窓の隙間からその鍵を彼らに託すことによって、むしろ彼らの安全が保証できるのではないかと考えるに至り、……毛布、食料を運び込むことでようやく納得してもらえたのだった。
It was fairly hard to get them to agree, but once they started thinking that their safety might actually be guaranteed if the key to the gardening storehouse was to be handed to them after being shut inside, ...and when it was decided that blankets and food would be carried in for them, they were finally convinced.

「………ここは寒々しいですねぇ…。私たちはいつまでここに閉じ込められていればいいのでしょうか……。」
"......This place is pretty chilly... I wonder how long we'll have to stay locked in here..."

「……下手をすると、月曜の朝まで、丸々一昼夜はいてもらうことになるかもしれない。……本当にお二人には申し訳なく思うよ…。」
"...It could be as late as Monday morning at the worst, so a full day and night. ...I really feel bad about doing this to you two..."

譲治は戦人と一緒に床の一部を片付け、そこに毛布を敷く。
そしてそこに、運び込んだ缶詰やクラッカーなどの軽食を置いた。
George and Battler cleared a space on the floor, then spread the blankets there.

They also left the canned food, crackers, and other light snacks they had brought.

「月曜の朝までを二人でこの量じゃ、辛いな…。せめて厨房に寄れたなら…。」
"It'll be hard for you guys to go until Monday with just this... If only we could make a trip to the kitchen..."

「余計な場所には行くなと言われてる。
"They said not to go anywhere we weren't told to.

……私たちは監視されてるらしいしな。………クソ。」
...Sounds like we're being watched. ...Damn."

「……何もお力になれないことを、申し訳なく思います……。こんな時に皆さんのお側にいてこその、私どもなのに………。」
"...I am honestly sorry that we cannot be of any use... And these are the times that we are truly supposed to be at your sides..."

「仕方ないです。……それより、熊沢さんをよろしく頼みますね。…何が起こるかわからない。
"It can't be helped. ...More importantly, take care of Kumasawa-san. We don't know what might happen.

いざという時は臨機応変に助けて欲しい。そして何よりも、無事でいて欲しい…。」
If the going gets tough, I'd like you to play it by ear and come to the rescue. And more than anything, I want you to be safe..."

「…えぇ、わかっています。……皆さんこそ気をつけてくださいね。今のお館様は、……まるで人の命を、チェスの駒のように奪います。…気をつけて下さい。」
"...Yes, I understand. ...Please be careful, everyone. Right now, the Master...is taking human lives like they're pieces on a chessboard. ...Please look out for yourselves."

郷田は俯き、未だに何が起こったのか信じられない、あの食堂での虐殺を思い出し、その恐ろしさを伝えきれずにいる自分の不甲斐なさに俯く。
Gohda stared at the floor, even now unable to believe what had happened as he remembered that atrocity in the dining hall, and he hung his head in shame at his failure to fully describe that terror.

「ありがとう。………くれぐれも注意して下さいね。熊沢さんも。」
"Thank you. ...Make sure you stay on your guard. You too, Kumasawa-san."

「……譲治さんたちも、くれぐれもご用心なさって下さいね……。もう、私には何が何やら、さっぱりわかりませんとも……。」
"...And you all please take care as well... I don't have any idea what's going on anymore..."

「それじゃ、……僕たちは行きます。行こう、戦人くん。朱志香ちゃん。……ほら、真里亞ちゃんも。」
"Well then, ...we'll be off. Let's go, Battler-kun, Jessica-chan. ...Come on, you too, Maria-chan."

「…………うー。」
"......Uu-."

閉じ込められる二人の痛々しい表情を見ていると、シャッターを下ろすのが辛くなる。
Looking at the pitiful expressions on the imprisoned pair's faces, it got really hard to close the shutter.

しかし、逆らえない。
……自分たちは監視されているのだ。
But we can't disobey.

...We're being watched.

シャッターを下ろし、施錠する。
そして譲治は、倉庫の脇の小さな窓へ向かう。
The shutter was brought down and locked.

Then, George walked toward the small window on the side of the storehouse.

それは格子が入った小さな窓で、明かり取りと換気くらいしか出来ないものだった。
At that side, there was a small latticed window that could only admit light and ventilation.

まるで牢屋を思わせ、ますますに不憫な気持ちになるが、……逆に彼らを、金蔵とその手下たちから守ってもいると考えたい…。
その窓を開け、呼び掛ける。
It looked like something from a jail, making the two of them seem even more pitiable, ...but on the other hand, it would hopefully protect them from Kinzo and his subordinates...

He opened the window and called out.

「……大丈夫ですか、寒くないですか。」
"...Are you okay? You aren't cold, are you?"

「えぇ。毛布をこんなにいただきましたからねぇ。……包まっていればきっと平気ですよ。」
"We're okay. You've given us so many blankets, after all. ...If we wrap ourselves up, we'll be just fine."

「石油ストーブとかを持ってくれば良かったな……。」
"I wish we could've brought them a kerosene stove or something..."

「……ここじゃ換気できないからね。辛いだろうけど、今は仕方がない。……僕たちは人質を取られている。逆らえない…。」
"...But it wouldn't have ventilation here. It'll probably be tough for them, but there's nothing we can do now. ...Hostages are being held against us. We can't disobey..."

「………畜生…。……何とか、霧江さんたちを救出することが出来れば……。」
"...Dammit... ...If we manage to save Kyrie and the rest somehow..."

「しっ。……聞かれてるかもしれないよ。………郷田さん、これ。そのシャッターの鍵です。」
"Shh. ...They might be listening. ...Gohda-san, here. It's the key to the shutter."

「……確かに。お預かりします。」
"...Indeed. I'll hold on to it."

郷田は鍵を受け取り、熊沢にもそれを見せた後、自らのポケットにしまう。
Gohda took the key, showed it to Kumasawa, and placed it in his own pocket.

園芸倉庫のシャッターの鍵はひとつしかない。
それを、閉じ込められた彼らに持たせるわけだ。
There's only one key to the gardening shed's shutter.

That key was being held by the ones locked up inside it.

鍵を子どもたちが持てば、万一の時、奪われでもしたら、倉庫の彼らの命をも危険に晒しかねないのだから。
If the children had kept it...and had it stolen from them by some chance, that would do nothing but expose the lives of those in the shed to danger.

それに、郷田たちに鍵が与えられても、内側から開くことは出来ない。金蔵の要求は満たす。
And even with the key, the shutter could not be opened from the inside. Kinzo's demands were fulfilled this way.

だが、外側からももはや如何なる方法でも開けることが出来ない。これは彼らの安全を守る。
However, there was now no longer any way to open the shed from the outside either. This protected them.

金蔵に命令されての監禁だが、……この寒々しい密室が、この二人を守ってくれると信じるしかない。
Kinzo had ordered that they be confined, ...and we could do nothing but trust that this cold closed room would protect them.

真里亞の手を握りながら、それを見守る朱志香は、真っ暗な薔薇庭園の茂みを見渡す。
Jessica watched this while holding Maria's hand, then looked over the thickets in the pitch-black rose garden.

……この暗がりのどこかに何者かが潜んでいて、自分たちが命令に従っているかどうか監視しているのだ。
...Somewhere in this darkness, somebody was hiding, watching to see whether we obeyed orders or not.

もちろん、懐中電灯を向けたところで、そこに不審な人影が浮かび上がることはない。
Of course, when we pointed our flashlights out there, no suspicious silhouettes appeared.

でも、きっと何者かが潜み、監視しているのだ。
But somebody was surely out there, ...hiding and watching.

その何者かに怒鳴りつけたい衝動に何度も駆られる。
……しかしそれを理性でぐっと抑え付けるのだった。
I was hit many times with an urge to scream at them.

...But I was able to hold that urge back through reason.

子どもたち４人は、何度も振り返りながら、その場を後にする。
The four children left the area, repeatedly looking back over their shoulders.

園芸倉庫内の頼りない電球の灯りが、わずかに漏れている。
The light from the faint lightbulb in the gardening storehouse was seeping out slightly.

……この狂った事件が何らかの形で決着し、……あの二人と再会することは、あるのだろうか。
...I wonder if this insane incident will come to an end somehow...so that we can meet those two again.

……譲治は、自ら閉めたあのシャッターの手応えが、…二人を自らの手で殺してしまったかのような、そんな風に感じられるのだった。
...To George, who had closed the shutter himself, ...the resistance of the lock had made it feel as though he'd killed them with his own hands.

「………それでも、……俺たちは逆らえないんだよな……。」
"...But even so, ...we can't defy them..."

「テストだと…。……クソジジイめ、ふざけやがって……！　それで母さんたちが殺されて、父さんたちが捕まって……。理解できねぇぜ、ぶっ殺してやる…！」
"What's with this test...? ...Damn geezer, don't screw with us...! Killing Mom, capturing Dad for that... I don't get it, I'll kill him...!"

「……大丈夫だよ、朱志香お姉ちゃん。悲しくなんかないよ……。」

Kinzo or one of his subordinates was listening to the conversation.

譲治、戦人、朱志香の３人は力強く頷き合い、拳をぶつけ合う。

そして朱志香は、指定された自分の部屋へ、ひとり向かっていく……。
Then, Jessica headed off to her own room, as designated...

彼女の姿が、暴風に揺れる暗闇の薔薇庭園に消えていく。
Her form disappeared into the darkness of the rose garden waving in the strong winds.

……それを見送り、譲治と戦人は握り拳をさらに硬くし、震わせるのだった……。

２階に残った真里亞は、窓から朱志香の背中を見送っている。
その表情はきょとんとしたもの……。
Left on the second floor, Maria watched Jessica's back through the window.

She wore a blank expression...

「……みんなは何を息巻いてるのかな。………ベアトリーチェが蘇れば、みんな生き返らせてもらえるのにね。」
"...I wonder what everyone's getting so upset about. ......Even though when Beatrice is revived, everyone will be brought back to life."

もう、朱志香の姿は闇に完全に飲み込まれてしまっている。
Jessica's form was already being completely swallowed up by the darkness.

……その時、再び電話が鳴る。
...At that time, the phone began to ring again.

戦人たちにも聞こえ、どたばたと大急ぎで戻ってくるが、それを待たずに真里亞が受話器を取る。
